sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Forgive thee! What:

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: O! Sir, I am the Occaſion of all this Noiſe and Anger.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Thou the Occaſion!

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: Indeed I'd never have offended your Honour ſo: but that my Conſcience drove me to't, whether I wou'd or no.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, what haſt done?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, Sir, this Man moſt fortunately overheard your Directions, to that wicked Inſtrument Mrs. Jewkes, and touch'd by Conſcience for his Concern, in what might happen diſcover'd the vile plot to me, and this was the occaſion (which your Jealouſy and Paſſion has ſo far miſtaken) of my Concealment.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! Is this Truth?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: Yes, indeed it is, and if your Honour pleaſes, I'll take my Bible-oath-on't.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, leave us. (Exit ARNOLD) Heav'ns! what an Eſcape Iv'e had from Rage and violent Deſire; to think upon it, is looking down a Precipice, from whence to have fall'n, I muſt have cruſh'd myſelf, and all beneath me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I find he's mov'd, I hope with juſt Remorſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And then this honeſt Man:—How has my ungovern'd Paſſion injur'd him, who has ſnatch'd me from the Depth of Guilt? How can I look on him?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mr. Williams, I wou'd ask your Pardon, but that I am too well convinc'd what I have done, won't bear Excuſe—therefore

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No more of that, Sir; as all the Merit of what I've done, is in the Deed itſelf, ſo your contrition brings with it an excuſe

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou excellent Man: What do I owe thee for thy hone •• help? Not leſs than if you'd ſnatcht me from the Hands of Death—Nay, I was dead to Virtue—but thus recover'd, I muſt repent—but firſt I muſt repair—or elſe my penitence deceives myſelf, and is but Mockery to Heaven. (Pauſes) It ſhall be ſo.—Mr. Williams, as you have been ſo great an inſtrument of my growing happineſs, I know your honeſt Nature cannot be more rewarded, than by compleating what you have ſo generouſly begun.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: How mean you, Sir:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: There's now no way left me to make amends for all the Wrongs I've done the virtuous Pamela, but by making her eternally my own.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sir, I applaud your reſolution, aad may Heaven make yon happy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It will not fail—my heart too prompts me to it—And then her beauty, and tranſcendent innocence, a re a large equivalent to Wealth and Title, and far outweigh their Worth.

l.hi: In lawleſs Pleaſures ſunk, to Virtue blind,
Thy friendly Care has rais'd my ſinking Mind
No more, by wild impetuous Tempeſts toſt,
With Horror now I view the fatal Coaſt;
By gentle Gales, my calmer Pasſions move,
My Pilot, Thou; my harbour Virtuous Love

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.p:
EITHER I am deceived, or yonder is the Priſon that confines my Pamela. I ſcarce have ſtrength
to reach it, and when I have, my Age and Circumſtances bring but ſmall Aſſiſtance—And who, alas? will ſide with injured Poverty againſt rich oppreſſion. Suppoſe I have recourſe to Mr. Belvile himſelf, and upon my knees beg him to reſtore my Daughter to her unhappy Father—if this imperious Fire of wanton youth has not wholly conſumed his Honour and Humanity, my Tears and Age perhaps may prove ſucceſsful Pleaders, and all be ſaved from Ruin? the Thought tranſports my Soul, and gives freſh Vigour to my wearied Body—Here comes onr may give me farther information.

What a plague does that old Fellow there, 'tis no Road I'm ſure, and none but Rogues wou'd make it one—I loſt ſome ſheep herabouts, laſt Midſummer was two years, and ten to one but this is the Man that ſtole 'em—Ecod I don't like his looks, and had I my Gun with me, I'd venture to ſhoot at 'en without examination, I wou'd—but I'll be ſharp and find 'en out.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray, honeſt Friend, is this the Road to Mr. Belvile's Houſe?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: (ſtares him in the Face, and whiſtles) Eh.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Is that Mr. Belvile's Houſe, Friend?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why do you think I'm Fool enough to tell you? Eh?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: You have Humanity enough, I hope, to inform a Stranger, without being guilty of Folly?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I won't tell you for all that; I am ſharp, Mun—You'll not get any thing from me, I can tell you but that: But pray you now, what may you want with 'Squire Beluile's Houſe?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I have particular Buſineſs there.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I don't doubt it, and every Rogue may have the ſame Buſineſs there for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I never was uſed to ſuch Language.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Noa; then you never had your deſerts before; He, he.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: You miſtake me, Friend, indeed; tho' I appear poor and unhappy, yet I am honeſt. (Weeps.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ecod, and ſo he is, I warrant him, may I be hang'd if I have not brought Tears into the Old 'en's Eyes; I'm ſorry I have been ſo harſh; pray you, don't take to Heart my Merriment; I'm ſorry I've wronged you, Father; but there are Rogues about, and I am a ſort of a Deputy-keeper to the 'Squire, and examine all ſuſpicious Perſons.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray, honeſt Friend, ſhew me the Houſe, for my Buſineſs with Mr. Beluile is very urgent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ay, but be it as urgent as it will, you'll find it hard Work to get him from the Buſineſs he's about; there's a tight Laſs in the Caſe, and the 'Squire is young and loveſome, and when a keen Stomach falls to good Meat, 'twill be hard to get him from it, till his Belly's full you know.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Oh, my Fears! Pray explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why, you muſt know; you're old enough to hold your Tongue, if I ſhould tell you?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: You may depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The young 'Squire has been deeply ſmitten with one of his own Maids, and all as he could ſay or do, the Wench kept her own till Yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: And what of Yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why all was over, I ſuppoſe, by the great Change; for ſhe has thrown away her home ſpun Country-dreſs, and is as fine as an Empreſs; (a bad Sign let me tell you) and he has thrown away his melancholy Humour, and is as skitiſh as a Colt; but ſhe'll tame him, eh, eh.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Enough; Farewell my Life and Cares; Pamela's undone; I'm no more. (Sinks in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What a murrain, is the Man out of his Senſes; what, old Friend, you are not dead ſure; I ſhall be brought into a fine Quandary here, an he dies without telling ſomebody I have not murdered him: Hold ye, his Breath comes and goes; there's Hopes yet.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p:
When ſhall I be at Reſt? Can I ſurvive my
Daughter's Infamy? All gracious Heav'n, let me not linger thus.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: There's ſomething preſſes him mightily; pray riſe, Maſter, and let me take you to the Hall, and get you ſomething to comfort you—Pray do.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: All Help is vain, 'tis Death alone can give me Peace; but I accept your kind Aſſiſtance (raiſes him.) If Age and Wretchedneſs deſerve Compaſſion, your Charity is well beſtow'd.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I never was ſo moved and terrified in all my Life.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray, Friend, direct me thither; and yet I dread to ſee her! But I muſt on, for Doubt but more perplexes and diſtracts my feeble Mind; if ſhe is ruin'd, I ſhall not long endure the Pain of thinking her Virtue was the laſt and only Prop of my declining Age, and both muſt ſink together.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Now, Pamela, guard well thy Mind; let not this ſudden, this amazing Turn of thy deſpairing Fortune—the pompous Height to which thou art rais'd—thro' gorgeous Dreſs—let 'em not throw upon thy former State a darkning Veil to hide its View—leſt Inſolence and Pride ſhou'd baniſh gentle Gratitude and fair Humility.

sp.speaker: Jewk.
sp.p: Good morrow, dear Madam—Well, if his Honour had choſe out of the Drawing room, on a Birth-night, I'll defy him to have brought home ſuch a Preſence for the Head of his Table—ſuch a delicate white and red, ſuch an Air, ſuch—

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Forbear—nor fondly hope to throw a Gloſs upon your former Conduct, by only changing Hands with Vice, and ſubſtituting in the Place of purpos'd Ruin, hateful Flattery.

sp.speaker: Jewk.
sp.p: Let me intreat your Ladyſhip to believe, whatever I have done was more thro' Fear of diſobeying his Honour, than any vicious Diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: The moſt vicious Diſpoſition is Want of Fear in diſobeying Heaven; and can there riſe a ſtronger Proof of ſuch a Want, than impiouſly attempting to draw others in to violate its ſacred Laws?

sp.speaker: Jewk.
sp.p: Dear Madam, the whole Service of my Life to come, ſhall be devoted to deſerve your Ladyſhip's Forgiveneſs.—

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: We'll wave this Subject for the preſent; and be aſſur'd, no proper Clemency from me ſhall be ever wanting, that your future Conduct may deſerve.

sp.speaker: Jewk.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladyſhip—has your Ladyſhip any Commands.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I have this Requeſt—that henceforth you decline beſtowing Titles I have neither Right or Inclination to—Supper muſt be deferr'd an Hour beyond the uſual Time, for the coming of Sir Simon Darnford, and his Family, whom Mr. Belvile is gone to invite.

sp.speaker: Jewk.
sp.p: I ſhall obſerve, Madam. (Exit

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: Odsheart, Madam, here's Lady Davers and her Nephew come—ſhe's in a main Heat—and ask'd for you Madam, as tho' ſhe were in a deſperate Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ha!—I thank you for this Notice. John—Conduct her in. (Exit. Arnold. This ſomewhat ruffles me—wou'd Mr. Belvile were at home! I dread this haughty Woman's Taunts—I think 'twere beſt to avoid her, till his Return—But wherefore ſhould I fear—the Guilty only fear; my Innocence is my Guard, which, if I had loſt, Shame, as well as Fear, indeed might juſtly have alarm'd me.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Protect us in the Name of Vanity, what nave we here? am I awake? Oh! I ſhall ſwoon.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am proud, Madam, of the Honour of ſeeing your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Oh: ſupport me. (Leaning upon Smatter.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Rat me, Madam, but I am debelitated with Surpriſe, equal to your Ladyſhip's.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Is not your Ladyſhip well?

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Well, no, I have the Vapours to Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Shall I order your Ladyſhip any thing?

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Order any thing, and why not fetch it thyſelf, Mrs. Pert.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I hop'd, Madam, paying my Duty here might be more agreeable.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: No, if thou wou'dſt have me recover, remove thyſelf in the Name of Decency, I conjure thee.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Madam, I ſhould occaſion this Diſorder—I'll retire (Going

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Stay.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I beſeech your Ladyſhip let her ſtay, for now I have recover'd my firſt Blaſt of Aſtoniſhment, let me periſh, but I'll ſupply the Want of Salvolatile and Hartſhorn for your Ladyſhiy, with a few Strokes of Wit and Humour upon this exotic Figure—Hearkee, Child, prithee do us the Favour of taking a turn or two croſs the Room, that we may arrive at ſome Degree of Certainty, whether or no thou art the identical little Pammy, formerly ſo famous for thy melifluous Structures of modern Tarts and Cheeſecakes?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, my Merit or your Capacity is ſo extremely ſlender, I can't be remembred for any thing more meritorious.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing Inſolence, I'm out of Patience, why thou gew-gaw Ideot, doſt thou imagine the fine Trappings Belv. has trick'd thee up in,—or the arrogant Pride of becoming his Miſtreſs—give thee a Pretence to this ſaucy Liberty with his Relations.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
Madam, I equally abhor the Thought of either, and wiſh this young Gentleman was as nearly related
to Mr. Belvile in his Senſe of Decency and good Manners, as he is by Blood or Marriage.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Well, throughout the whole Race of female Delinquents, henceforth I'll eternally celebrate the non-pareil of kept Abigail.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Remember, Sir, this wanton Licence, with my Character and Reputation, equally reflects upon Mr. Belvile's.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Now that, Child, is what I can't ſo readily comprehend—becauſe, you muſt know, we young Fellows think our Reputation's as little concern'd in debauching every Girl we like, as in beating every Drawer or Hackney-Coachman we do not like. [Apart to her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Shameleſs and abandon'd Principles!

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Ay, that may be; but they are the Principles of moſt of the ſmart young Fellows in Town.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: But know, Sir, they are ſuch as Mr. Belvile's Honour and good Senſe deteſts and loaths.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: What, what, Madam, are you pleas'd to inſinuate relating to Mr. Belvile's Senſe and Honour—good Mrs. Forward, none of thy Works of Supererogation, that is, to come down to the Level of thy Underſtanding; don't meddle in Defence of his Honour, till you have a better Right, and are properly call'd upon; thy Underſtanding, Child, as well as thy Perſon, is in Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Dear Lady Davers, you never were more out in your Life—the Deſign of Maſquerades is to conceal Perſons, you know—Now Pammy's Dreſs is quite the contrary; for it very plainly diſcovers who ſhe is, and what ſhe is—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what am I?

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: As fine a Woman as e'er my Eyes beheld; by all that's exquiſite, Tom Belvile's a moſt happy Mortal, or may I ſuffer Annihilation.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p:
Pretty Dear: I'll aſſure you it has got a Spirit with its fine Cloaths—what are you painted too, Cherubim? 'Gads, my life: 'tis very neceſſary—
you'll be pale and ſickly by-and-by—Qualms, Qualms, my Dear, will ſoon fetch out the Ruddineſs of your Cheeks—I beg ten thouſand Pardons—the Roſes I wou'd ſay.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Upon my Soul, Lady Davers, I think Pammy has a very pretty Fancy; I never ſaw Cloaths more Alamode in my Life; the Colour, Silk, and Trimmings, quite genteel—white, white, you know, is quite apropos for Pammy, and emblematical—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Virgin Colour—I always thought Pamela would die a Veſtal—ſhe's a very Martyr to Virtue, and the very Picture of Purity—

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Oh fort bien—fort bien, Madam—

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: This Treatment is inſupportable. [Burſting into Tears, going.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Pamela in Tears? What has diſturb'd my Love?

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Why you muſt know, Sir, my Lady here, and I, being enlighten'd with the Brilliancy of Pammy's Figure, have been ſomewhat ſprightly in our Remarks upon her Tranſmutation—and ſhe, poor Thing, not uſed to that Spirit in Converſing, had no other Hope to extinguiſh the Fire of our Raillery, but by Tears—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What you term Raillery—I find was Inſolence; for, all thy poor Attempts toward Wit, her ſlighteſt Breath had blaſted in their Birth.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Brother, Brother,—I am ſorry to find in Relations are thus treated with Contempt for this worthleſs—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hold, Madam—By Heaven, the Worth of half your Sex, weighed in the Ballance againſt her's, is light and inconſiderable—

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: O doubtleſs, Sir, the Worth of a favourite Miſtreſs is ineſtimable, in the Opinion of her Admirer, at leaſt while the deluding Bait of Novelty continues, and the Nymph's adorable Charms remain in Bloom, and unfaded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Tho' Female Envy muſt allow the perſonal Charms of Pamela, yet the Beauties of her Mind ſo far exceed 'em, they ſtand in Rivalſhip with the moſt Correct and truly Elevated of our Sex.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ſhe has given elevated Proofs indeed of a prodigious correct Mind, in chooſing rather to make you Guardian of her Honour and Innocence, than keep Poſſeſſion of 'em herſelf.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She has, Madam, in the juſteſt Senſe, made me Guardian of her Honour: I am her Husband.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Husband.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and prouder of the Name, than all the empty Pomp that Fortune, Birth, or Title, can beſtow.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Sir, I go Poſt for London To-morrow Morning; do you chooſe Lodgings in Moorfields, Chelſea, or Bednal-Green?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hence, thou Trifler.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Raving, by Endymion; and poſitively may be miſchievous, therefore 'tis prudect to withdraw, tii is fit cools, 'egad. (Aſide)

div.stage: "During this Time, Lady Davers appears greatly diſorder'd, and views Pamela with great Anger and Contempt—ſits down, takes out a Smelling-bottle, then a Snuff-box."

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: My Preſence, Sir, I perceive, but more increaſes the Indignation Lady Davers is thus ſuddenly alarm'd with; therefore beg Leave to withdraw, leſt I prevent a Reconciliation I moſt ardently deſire.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Your Prudence and good Senſe have only prevented my Requeſt—that you might not be diſturb'd with her outrageous Inſolence and Pride—I'll wait on you in the Garden immediately, my Life. (Leading her to the door)

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: What! is ſhe gone? You did well to ſend her out of the Way—for by the Infamy ſhe throw • upon our Blood— • — • —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ceaſe your idle Threats—Virtue and Innocence add Luſtre to the nobleſt Blood.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, our's wanted no ſuch Addition.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Part on't wants Meekneſs and Humility—they would make you new, like me: This lovely Creature's Merit, as it ſtands enrich'd by Nature, is regardleſs of the Gifts of Accident or Fortune.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Provoking Folly; and do you really imagine, Sir, this pretty romantick Encomium upon Nature, and her fiddle-faddle Gifts, will make any Atonement for the eternal Blemiſh thrown on the Honour of our Name and Family?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I well know you have been fatally miſled, by too many Precedents, to conclude Pride and Haughtineſs the chief Charactericks of Name and Family.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I ſhall ſo far perſevere in that Error—never meanly to acknowledge as my Relation any mean pitiful—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By Heaven! if you but whiſper one the ſlighteſt Accent may reflect on her I have thought fit to ſhare my Name and Fortune with, that Moment is the laſt you ever ſhall be called, or even remember'd as a Siſter—Farewell, (Going.)

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Stay, I conjure you (burſting into Tears) Alas, my Brother, you too ſeverely load me with the Charge of Pride—while thus, behold, your warm Concern, and ſharp Reſentment, ſubdues its utmoſt Force, and change to Tenderneſs its boaſted Strength.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Prithee no more; I am convinced thoſe Violences of Temper, that ſo frequently break out, are more contracted by Habit and ill Example, than any natural Tendency in your Diſpoſi ion; and be aſſured, my Dear, when you are thoroughly acquainted with Pamela's great Worth and Merit, you will readily confeſs I have the faireſt Proſpect for a continual Series of ſocial Happineſs, the chief Bleſſing of the married State.

sp.speaker: L Da.
sp.p: I have, as well as you, a very high Opinion of Pamela's Merit—Yet—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Beware of a Relapſe, let me entreat you, follow her into the Garden, and now your Paſſion ſomewhat
ſubſides, I am convinced the Force of her good Senſe, and winning Affability in conveying that Senſe, will quickly baniſh your falſe Punctilios of Birth and Family.

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: If they ſhould fail, the tender Wiſhes I muſt ever have, to hold a Place in your Affections, ſhall henceforth govern all my Thoughts. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Honour, Maſter Andrews is without, and preſſes very hard to ſee your Honour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, Mr. Andrews, admit him immediately. (Exit Arn) This good old Man, no doubt, is come with a heavy anxious Heart, apprehenſive of his Daughter's Ruin, 'twere beſt I think to leave the Pleaſure of undeceiving him to her, becauſe 'twill ſo agreeably increaſe the Joy.
Good Mr. Andrews, your Servant; I am extremely glad to ſee.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I thank you Sir,—Pardon my Impatience, Sir, where is my Child?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I believe, i'th' Garden.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: She's well, I hope?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O never better—gay as the Spring, and beautiful as ever.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I am not ſolicitous to know in what Condition the Beauty of her Perſon ſtands, provided that of her Mind is ſtill preſerv'd unblemiſh'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sure, Mr. Andrews you don't imagine ſhe has any Examples in my Family to corrupt it?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I hope there are not, Sir, but pardon me, if the fond Tears of an indulgent Father ſtruggle againſt that Hope, and guſh with ſilent Anguiſh from my Eyes. (Weeping.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Twere cruel longer to continue him under this Anxiety.
Let Pamela know I deſire to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: She and Lady Davers, Sir, are here. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Here's a Stranger, Pamela—

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: My Father; (Running to him and kneeling.)

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: (Turning from her) Wou'd I were not.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Alas, what mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: View thy own ſumptuous Dreſs—and tell thyſelf my Meaning.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Oh, my lov'd Father, baniſh your Fears, nor think your Daughter's Innocence the hateful Barter for this coſtly Habit; 'tis made the Purchaſe, not the Exchange: for know, this worthy Gentleman, won by my conſtant Firmneſs to the virtuous Principles your Goodneſs early taught me, has rais'd me juſtly to the Honour of his Bed; I am his Wife.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: How ſhall my ſudden declining Strength ſupport this ſudden Flood of Joy? O my Child, my Child; (Weeping and embracing her)

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is not the Power of thus rewarding virtuous Truth, my Siſter, the nobleſt Pride the Heart can boaſt?

sp.speaker: L. Da.
sp.p: Believe me, Brother, I want no Arguments to enforce its Truth.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: My Surpriſe and Joy too long prevent my Gratitude—O worthy Sir, what Words, what Thoughts ſufficiently can pay—?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The ampleſt Payment is the Bleſſing of that honeſt upright Heart upon this happy Union. (Takes Pamela by the Hand, and both Kneel.)

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Spare me this Confuſion, Sir, receive it in my Wiſhes, I have not Words. (Raiſing 'em, and turning away.

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, by Aſtraea and her Scales, ha, ha, ha, the drolleſt and moſt conſummate Piece of Juſtice, ha, ha, ha, the Goddeſs, Madam, (to Pam.) points you out as her peeuliar Favourite; for ſhe has not only wrought the Confuſion of your inveterate
Enemy, but alſo the Converſion of your moſt devoted humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Smat.
sp.p: Why, in the firſt Place, Sir, a worthy Gentleman, by giving me the moſt prevailing as well as pleaſing Detail of this Lady's amiable Conduct and Qualities, has made me a ſincere Convert to Women of Honour and Virtue. And this Paper, Sir,—this Paper, left by your Valet de Chambre, Colebrand, will humourouſly deſcribe the Puniſhment ſo juſtly inflicted on that venerable Matron Madamoiſelle Jewkes.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Pray oblige us, Sir, with reading it.

body.p: I Send a you dis Lettre, to let a you know you ſal never ſee me any more, upon my Vard—I do confeſs I have marie with you, and auci, I do confeſs dat de Marriage is a grande Engagement; but I no tink dere is a great Mal to break de grande Engagement, ven it is very apropos—I have told a you, p • aſieurs fois, dat you had great Beauti and Temtation about you; which, en verite, vas your Mone—And now I have got dat in my Poſſeſſion, de reſte of Madam Jewkes may allon au Diable—Dat is more French Politique for you. I have a very good Wife in my own Country, and tirteen little pretty Enfans, all like myſelf, which your good Guinea ſal make alive fort bien: If you can perſuade any great Fool to marie you vidout de Portion, you have my Conſentiment, de tou mon Coeur! For, upon my Vard, Madam Jewkes, you are a damn'd heretique old Vitch, and are more proper for Monſieur de Devil, dan for

closer.signed: Your tres humble Serviteur, at a Diſtance, JAQUES COLEBRAND.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I cou'd wiſh this evil Woman's Puniſhment had been accompliſhed, without the Addition of another's Crime.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Give me Leave to intercede, ſhe may not, Sir, be wholly deſtitute—leſt Want prevent that Penitence your Clemency may win.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How exalted is the Mind prefering Mercy to Revenge.

Sir, that I might contribute as much as poſſible to enlarge the Pleaſure ſo general in your Family, I have prepared a little muſical Entertainment, in which your Neighbours and Servants have deſired to be employ'd as Performers, and they now wait your Commands.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Whenever they pleaſe, Mr. Williams.
Sir, I am greatly obliged to you, and moſt particularly ſo, in becoming the happy Inſtrument of diſcovering to me, the ineſtimable Merit of this lovely Woman, which I had before too lightly view'd.
sp.l: The Indian thus, with wanton Dalliance play'd

l.hi: O'er the firſt Diamond, he by Chance ſurvey'd;
But when its hidden Fire, like Day, broke forth,
And blazing prov'd its fix'd intrinſic Worth,
Like me, its latent Beauties he explor'd,
And what before he priz'd, he then ador'd.

lg.l: HOLD, Critics, what's your Sentence e're you go?
Say, is our Bard pronounc'd an Aſs or no?
Or do you wiſely nod your Hods, and cry, So, ſo.
Well, entre nous, I think him ſtrangely dull,
A ſenſeleſs, ſtupid, antiquated Fool;
Was ever ſuch another Blockhead ſeen?
To chooſe a Servant for his Heroine;
Gad, on our Sex, a general Satire's thrown,
Who love more cheap to part with—what's their own.
If this ſhould paſs, all Womankind muſt fear,
For none will purchaſe, if the Sale's ſo dear.
Unhappy Belvile, what a Wife, protect her,
N • doubt he'd often have a Curtain Lecture.
Beſides, a Girl, ſo over-fond of Grace,
Might be devout in an improper Place;
And pour forth Sermons from her fervent Mind,
When the poor Man's • uite otherwiſe inclin'd.
I promiſe you, I've try'd my utmoſt Art,
To wipe theſe muſty Tenets from his Heart;
But he's reſolv'd to give the World the Lye,
And like his Pammy, conquer Vice or die.
So let him fall; unhappy, little Bays.
But firſt I'll tell you what the Ninny ſays.
He knew his Judges, and he wiſh'd to find
A Theme might juſtly pleaſe a Britiſh Mind:
A Tale, which Albion's Sons might deign to hear,
And without Shame, let fall the pitying Tear.
If then theſe well-meant Scenes have Pow'r t'impart
One Moment's Pleaſure to the virtuous Heart;
If humble Truth and Innocence can move
Your Souls, like Belvile's, to reward and love;
His artleſs Muſe in after times ſhall ſing
Theſe noble Topicks on a bolder Wing;
And the warm Spark your Breath has help'd to raiſe,
Collect its Fires, and mount into a Blaze.
